description: Hungary mid-consolidation under Orbán's second term
period_notes: Five years into Fidesz rule; new constitution in effect; EU tensions escalating

checkpoint_notes.C2: Constitutional Court packed and jurisdiction stripped; no longer independent check
checkpoint_notes.C4: Prosecutor's office aligned with government; selective enforcement emerging
checkpoint_notes.D3: New electoral law favors Fidesz; winner-take-all in many districts
checkpoint_notes.E1: Major independent media bought by government allies; MTI (state news) dominates
checkpoint_notes.E3: State media heavily biased; independent outlets marginalized but still exist
checkpoint_notes.F1: Civil service purged; loyalists in key positions

flag_notes.expertise_void: Career civil servants replaced with loyalists; institutional memory degraded
flag_notes.institutional_resistance: Some resistance from remaining independent media, civil society, and EU

narrative: By 2015, Hungary had completed the first phase of democratic backsliding. The constitution had been rewritten, courts packed, and media landscape transformed. However, the system remained formally democratic: elections occurred, opposition parties existed, and some independent media survived. The EU maintained pressure but lacked enforcement tools. This represents the 'competitive authoritarian' transition point—democracy is hollowed out but the shell remains. Elections become increasingly unfair but not fraudulent. Courts defer to government but occasionally rule against it. This baseline shows what mid-stage consolidation looks like: the point where reversal becomes difficult but not yet impossible.
scholarly_sources: Scheppele, Kim Lane. 'Autocratic Legalism.' University of Chicago Law Review 85 (2018): 545-583
Bozóki, András and Dániel Hegedűs. 'An Externally Constrained Hybrid Regime: Hungary in the European Union.' Democratization 25, no. 7 (2018): 1173-1189
Mudde, Cas. 'The 2014 Hungarian Parliamentary Elections, or How to Craft a Constitutional Majority.' Washington Post, April 14, 2014
comparison_guidance: Hungary 2015 represents the tipping point into competitive authoritarianism. Use this baseline to assess whether backsliding has progressed beyond early warning into structural entrenchment. A score matching Hungary 2015 suggests that normal democratic competition has been fundamentally compromised.
